> The diff coverage is `12.72%`.

------

[Continue to review full report at Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/22403?src=pr&el=continue).
> **Legend** - [Click here to learn more](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-delta)
> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/22403?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [9f6c02d...4d7fa1c](https://codecov.io/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/22403?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

Here are two examples of the bubble plots produced with numeric and categorical data.

**Numeric bubble size data:**

```python
df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.rand(50, 3), columns=['a', 'b', 'c'])
df.plot.scatter(x='a', y='b', s='c')
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/27647971/44311008-31e6a100-a3e0-11e8-93f0-0997c93e3a60.png)

The auto generated legend adapts to the maximum value to be represented and always has round values.

---
**Ordered categorical bubble size data:**

```python
surf_area = np.concatenate([40.0 + 80.0 * np.random.rand(30),
                            80.0 + 160.0 * np.random.rand(20),
                            100.0 + 200.0 * np.random.rand(10)])

types = np.array(30*['Flat'] + 20*['House'] + 10*['Castle'])
prices = 0.01 * surf_area * (np.random.rand(60) + 1.5) / 2
prices *= np.array([1]*30 + [1.4]*20 + [2]*10)
property_types = pd.Categorical(types, categories=['Flat', 'House', 'Castle'], ordered=True)
df = pd.DataFrame({
   'Surface area (sqm)': surf_area,
   'Price (M€)': prices,
   'Property type': property_types
})

df.loc[[0, 1, 30, 31, 50, 51], :]
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/27647971/44311122-02389880-a3e2-11e8-8dbd-7ce91da9e73e.png)


```python
df.plot.scatter(x='Surface area (sqm)', y='Price (M€)',
                s='Property type', alpha=.5);
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/27647971/44311107-aec64a80-a3e1-11e8-8966-e226761f58d3.png)
@TomAugspurger Since you followed this from the start your comments would be highly appreciated! Thx Vincent

Hello @VincentAntoine! Thanks for updating the PR.

 - There are no PEP8 issues in the file [`pandas/plotting/_core.py`](https://github.com/VincentAntoine/pandas/blob/cd1a636bec61743922b3f7e9dbc63f5d6c874379/pandas/plotting/_core.py) !

 - There are no PEP8 issues in the file [`pandas/tests/plotting/test_frame.py`](https://github.com/VincentAntoine/pandas/blob/cd1a636bec61743922b3f7e9dbc63f5d6c874379/pandas/tests/plotting/test_frame.py) !

I would tend to follow matplotlib's lead here.

https://matplotlib.org/api/_as_gen/matplotlib.pyplot.plot.html does say
scatter plots are "sometimes also called bubble chart" in an aside. We can
do something similar.

Was scheduled for September I think. No worries, I'll see if I have time to push the changes myself, as it's almost done.
rebase. @VincentAntoine @datapythonista @TomAugspurger if you'd have a look.

I've been checking this, and personally I don't think we should add these changes to pandas. If I'm not wrong, generating the desired plots in pandas is possible with `s=df['col']` and adding the legend after the plot has been generated. For a bit of syntactic sugar of being able to use `s='col'` and implementing a legend that won't be customizable, we are adding a lot of complexity (including a function `_sci_notation` that shouldn't be in the scatter, or in plots in general).

> I'm not wrong, generating the desired plots in pandas is possible with
s=df['col'] and adding the legend after the plot has been generated.

Not quite. That generates an exact mapping between the value in `df['col']`
and the radius of the marker. This isn't user-friendly since
you need to scale the data to something reasonable for matplotlib before
doing the plot. This may be a complex non-linear transformation,
depending on the data.

This PR implements a kind of binning (which libraries like ggplot do),
which can make the visualization easier to understand.

FWIW, I notice now that seaborn has a scatterplot method:
https://seaborn.pydata.org/generated/seaborn.scatterplot.html

On Wed, Nov 21, 2018 at 3:21 PM Marc Garcia <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> I've been checking this, and personally I don't think we should add these
> changes to pandas. If I'm not wrong, generating the desired plots in pandas
> is possible with s=df['col'] and adding the legend after the plot has
> been generated. For a bit of syntactic sugar of being able to use s='col'
> and implementing a legend that won't be customizable, we are adding a lot
> of complexity (including a function _sci_notation that shouldn't be in
> the scatter, or in plots in general).
>

I missed that part, thanks for clarifying.

Wouldn't be a better approach to simply have a method that does the binning, and apply it always to `s` (I assume that we want that `s='col'` and `s=df['col']` returns the same thing).

I think that is much simpler than what's implemented here.
closing. if you want to continue, pls ping. needs to merge master and update to comments.
